title: OpenAI’s hunger for data is coming back to bite it

last_post.content: Agree with conclusion of this piece: “...where working on data is seen as silly work and working on models is seen as real work.” https://www.technologyreview.com/2023/04/19/1071789/openais-hunger-for-data-is-coming-back-to-bite-it/ @mmitchell_ai Even in research, so many conferences and workshops skip straight over data provenance, cleaning, reconciliation, metadata, permissions, record keeping etc. As someone responsible for a research data management plan service that's been an ongoing frustration. Needs much more attention.

title: Fedi.Tips – An Unofficial Guide to Mastodon and the Fediverse

last_post.content:
For everyone who is #NewHere / #NeuHier, don't forget to post an #introduction with lots of hashtags to help people who share your interests find you (in general, hashtags are searchable but the full text of peole's posts is not).

Check out #FediTips or follow @feditips to get pointers as you settle in, or read through https://fedi.tips at your leisure

And don't be afraid to ask questions! We were all #NewHere once and had to learn the ropes. (Feel free to ask me if you're unsure about asking others :) )

I'm revising the Python version of https://third-bit.com/sdxjs/ over the summer. I want to create lecture slides as well as prose, but am struggling to find tools to keep them in sync. Closest I've found is to put the chapter text as speaker's notes in the slides so that each chunk/episode of teaching is co-located, then use a script to extract the notes and collate them to produce the prose page for the chapter. It's awkward for many reasons (e.g., figures in speaker's notes). Is there a better way?

High time to learn about #knowledgegraph technology. Register now for our new free #OpenHPI online lecture "Knowledge Graphs - Foundations and Applications" starting in Oct 2023:
https://open.hpi.de/courses/knowledgegraphs2023

How to find a new server?

Look around at the people you follow and interact with. Chances are, a lot of them are not on the same server as you are. Check out the local timelines of theirs, see if you like the vibe. Also, ask around.

Check out #FindAServer to see some options right away or take a look over at https://fedi.garden. They have a large curated list of servers to pick from.

Some servers (like ours) don't have fully open registrations and require manual approval of accounts. It's usually to protect from spammers (and worse, and it's very effective). Don't get that discourage you, just request an account, it's fine.

Always read Ed Yong!

I'm glad he's back from his sabbatical, and glad his first piece addresses Long Covid.

"The people who still live with COVID are being ignored so that everyone else can live with ignoring it."

https://www.theatlantic.com/health/archive/2023/04/long-covid-symptoms-invisible-disability-chronic-illness/673773/

Paywall-free: https://archive.is/xAIJn

title: Study Results: How well do harassment prevention interventions transfer between communities?

last_post.content:
In oral arguments, Supreme Court justices asked a question that we can answer with science: do policies against harassment cause a chilling effect on freedom of expression?

In multiple large-scale field experiments, we have found that policies that restrict harmful speech actually increase the free exercise of speech rights.

Here's our latest data: https://citizensandtech.org/2022/08/harassment-prevention-across-communities/

title: Pluralistic: What the fediverse (does/n’t) solve (23 Dec 2022) – Pluralistic: Daily links from Cory Doctorow

last_post.content:
@JoeRess Jim hit the nail on the head with Mastodon's biggest win; Being able to pack up your social graph is very important.

@pluralistic refers to it as "Freedom of Exit" -- but, there's also "Freedom of Reach", that is just as important:

https://pluralistic.net/2022/12/23/semipermeable-membranes/

Keep chipping away at them, Joe! Great episode.

RT @nelsonfliu@twitter.com

Generative search engines are transforming how we find info, but are they trustworthy?

We evaluate Bing Chat, NeevaAI, http://perplexity.ai & YouChat—only 52% of statements are supported by cites and 75% of cites actually support their statements.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2304.09848

🧵

🐦🔗: https://twitter.com/nelsonfliu/status/1649075151303221249

title: Emergency Rule Seriously Restricts Trans Health Care For Adults, Minors in Missouri

last_post.content:
If you're cis, I'd like you to read this article and learn that Missouri is about to enact a full ban on transition healthcare for transgender people. The deadline is April 27.

No cisgender person I've shared this with has had any idea that this is a ban, not a regulation - the requirements are impossible to meet.

I would also ask that you share this information with three other cis people today, preferably ones in or near #Missouri .

Thank you.

https://gizmodo.com/missouri-trans-gender-affirming-care-ban-adults-order-1850337858

title: What It’s Like To Stop Using Google Search - Debugger

last_post.content:
"What It's Like To Stop Using Google Search"

Most of the time I don't notice a thing ...

... because a surprisingly large fraction of my searches are navigational ("where's the site for that *thing* again?") or informational at a level that's trivially easy for any search service at all

So the actual cost of switching is ... pretty low

(DuckDuckGo's my main search these days)

My essay on it: https://debugger.medium.com/what-its-like-to-stop-using-google-search-fbdf9919c551

"Friend" link if you're not a Medium subscriber: https://debugger.medium.com/what-its-like-to-stop-using-google-search-fbdf9919c551?sk=723a09d252b9f8558f08e1551b2b6896

title: An Evaluation on Large Language Model Outputs: Discourse and Memorization

last_post.content:
An Evaluation on Large Language Model Outputs: Discourse and Memorization

80.0% of the outputs of LLMs evaluated contained memorized data, but outputs containing the most memorized content were also more likely to be considered of high quality.

title: Work with the Reporters Committee for Freedom of the Press

last_post.content: Hello #legal mastodon! The Reporters Committee for freedom of the Press is hiring three (3!) full-time positions for media and #1A attorneys in DC and around the country. RCFP is looking to hire: (1) a Staff Attorney to support the Reporters Committee’s Local Legal Initiative (LLI) and other legal programming; (2) a Staff Attorney to lead our amicus brief practice; and (3) an Oklahoma Local Legal Initiative Attorney. Details here: https://www.rcfp.org/work-at-rcfp/#ft Please share!

title: Farmers ‘crippled’ by satellite failure as GPS-guided tractors grind to a halt

last_post.content:
A signal failure stalled GPS-dependent tractors across farms in Australia and New Zealand, after one of the Inmarsat satellites providing accuracy enhancements to GPS in that part of the earth stopped working correctly: https://www.smh.com.au/national/farmers-crippled-by-satellite-failure-as-gps-guided-tractors-grind-to-a-halt-20230418-p5d1de.html, via https://news.ycombinator.com/item?id=35643705

The satellite is back after an over-24-hour outage but this event "is prompting farmers and industry groups to examine their backup systems for the technology they are using": https://www.abc.net.au/news/rural/2023-04-19/inmarsat-i-4-f1-satellite-operating-again-after-outage/102239674

title: Mike Lindell’s firm told to pay $5 million in ‘Prove Mike Wrong’ election-fraud challenge

last_post.content:
Such a great and welcome scoop:

"MyPillow founder and prominent election denier Mike Lindell made a bold offer ahead of a “cyber symposium” he held in August 2021 in South Dakota: He claimed he had data showing Chinese interference and said he would pay $5 million to anyone who could prove the material was not from the previous year’s U.S. election.

He called the challenge “Prove Mike Wrong.”

On Wednesday, a private arbitration panel ruled that someone did.

The panel said Robert Zeidman, a computer forensics expert and 63-year-old Trump voter from Nevada, was entitled to the $5 million payout."

https://www.washingtonpost.com/investigations/2023/04/20/mike-lindell-prove-wrong-contest/?utm_campaign=wp_post_most&utm_medium=email&utm_source=newsletter&wpisrc=nl_most&carta-url=https%3A%2F%2Fs2.washingtonpost.com%2Fcar-ln-tr%2F39c687b%2F64416907afd891675414cbcb%2F6115d88dade4e221cc5dd56a%2F8%2F72%2F64416907afd891675414cbcb&wp_cu=7929632d97e70e504426c12bc240d339%7CC96859F95B4949C1E0530100007F89BB

title: As Transgender America struggles, national news doesn’t know what to write

last_post.content:
We've all heard the critiques of the national news coverage by now. The legislative attacks on trans rights are, in some ways, unprecedented. Dozens of states copy-and-pasting the same handful of laws, passing them all at once. It's a strategy designed to defeat reporters, who need somthing new to say.

Today for the Objective I went behind the headlines to talk to reporters about why and where national coverage of anti-trans legislation is breaking down.

https://objectivejournalism.org/2023/04/as-transgender-america-struggles-national-news-doesnt-know-what-to-write/

last_post.content:
Buzzfeed is shutting down its news division because despite winning a Pulitzer Prize, “it never made money.”

title: The Pile: An 800GB Dataset of Diverse Text for Language Modeling

last_post.content:
The white paper for the Pile, a dataset used for many #AI projects (including key #opensource AI efforts) is a fascinating read.

It's managed by a mysterious group called the Eye, it includes things like pirated books and subtitles (for pirated movies) and it has a very interesting take on open science, strongly skewed towards research freedom and pragmatism of accessing and using data.

What I want to highlight here is that the dataset also includes a corpus of @europarl_en from over 20 years.

Anyone who follows the EP legislative process knows it's extremely #oldschool, with little sense that there are collective knowledge management tools that could significantly facilitate the process, make it more transparent and engaging, etc.

So it's interesting to see it end up as a foundational bit for large language models.

I will now be imagining the outputs being just a bit tinged with European political talk.

https://arxiv.org/abs/2101.00027

What is the nearest big city to where you live? How has the climate already changed there?

You can now explore and download Warming Stripes graphics for over 450 cities around the world. They show how temperatures have already changed over the last 100+ years.

And, all the warming stripes have been updated to include 2022, with many extended back further in time.

#ShowYourStripes

https://www.ShowYourStripes.info
